clinical_study.brief_title: Using Smart Phone Technology To Rural Veterans
clinical_study.official_title: USING SMART PHONE TECHNOLOGY AS A PLATFORM FOR DELIVERING MENTAL HEALTH CARE TO RURAL VETERANS

lead_sponsor.agency: Michael Debakey Veterans Affairs Medical Center

collaborator.agency: South Central VA Mental Illness Research, Education & Clinical Center

clinical_study.source: Michael Debakey Veterans Affairs Medical Center

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to see if a new Smart Phone application can help Veterans manage their panic symptoms after completing a two-day treatment for panic attacks.

detailed_description.textblock:
The first goal is to see how helpful the Smart Phone application is in helping veterans with panic symptoms continue to improve after you complete treatment.
The second goal of this study is to find out how much veterans like the Smart Phone application.
The third goal is to see how practical it is to use the Smart Phone application as a form of follow-up care. We want to see how much time is needed to provide technical support in using the application.

primary_outcome.description: A cognitive-behavioral therapy for PD that is highly efficacious, the standard delivery format of these sessions are typically offered once a week over a period of several months. This can pose challenges to rural Veterans who have multiple commitments and face long travel distances for mental health services. To improve accessibility to panic treatment, one innovative approach has been to deliver PCT in an intensive, two-day format.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Participants must
1. be an Operation Enduring Freedom/Operation Iraqi Freedom/Operation New Dawn (OEF/OIF/OND) Veteran
2. currently meet criteria for PD with or without Agoraphobia
3. complete the weekend PD treatment at the Lufkin, Conroe or Texas City CBOC.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. current substance dependence
2. organic psychosis
3. symptomatic bipolar disorder
4. severe depression with suicidal intent or plan
5. cognitive impairment (indicated by scores <20 on SLUMS)
